CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. "highest J sc and FF" - Here, J sc and FF are performance parameters of the device, not material names.
2. "inferior polymer chain packing" - "polymer" is a material name.
3. "active layer" - The material of this layer is not specified in the text.
4. "alkyl side chains" - "Alkyl" is a functional group, and it is a part of a material, not a material name itself.
5. "tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14" - Here, "tetradecyl" is an alkyl group, and "PffBB-14" is a material name.
6. "champion PffBB-14 - based device" - PffBB-14 is a material name.
7. "alkyl side chain" - Alkyl is a functional group, and it is a part of a material, not a material name itself.
8. "PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs" - PffBB-n and PC71BM are material names.
9. "PffBB-n polymers" - PffBB-n is a material name.
10. "well - ordered polymer : PC71BM network / packing" - PffBB-n and PC71BM are material names.
11. "PffBB-n - based devices" - PffBB-n is a material name.
12. "hole - only and electron - only devices" - These are types of devices, not material names.
13. "PffBB-n:PC71BM blend" - PffBB-n and PC71BM are material names.

Material names identified: polymer, PffBB-14, PffBB-n, PC71BM.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| polymer |
| PffBB-14 |
| PffBB-n |
| PC71BM |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. J sc: Short for "short-circuit current density." It is a measure of the current produced by a solar cell under short-circuit conditions.
2. FF: Short for "fill factor." It is a measure of the quality of a solar cell and is defined as the ratio of the maximum power point to the product of the open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current.
3. Polymer chain packing: This refers to the way in which the polymer chains are arranged in the active layer of the solar cell. Inferior polymer chain packing can lead to a poor charge transporting network, which can decrease the efficiency of the solar cell.
4. Alkyl side chains: These are chains of carbon and hydrogen atoms that are attached to the polymer backbone. The length of the alkyl side chains can affect the processability and interchain interactions of the polymer, which can in turn affect the efficiency of the solar cell.
5. π-π stacking interactions: These are interactions between the conjugated π systems of the polymer backbone. Optimizing the π-π stacking interactions can lead to a highly ordered molecular packing, which can improve the efficiency of the solar cell by facilitating charge transport.
6. External quantum efficiency (EQE): This is a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell in converting incident photons into electrical current.
7. Photoconversion response: This refers to the ability of a solar cell to convert light into electrical current.
8. Charge carrier mobilities: This refers to the ability of charge carriers (such as electrons and holes) to move through the solar cell. Higher charge carrier mobilities can lead to higher current densities and fill factors.
9. Space-charge-limited current (SCLC) model: This is a model used to estimate the charge carrier mobilities of a solar cell.
10. Charge dissociation probability: This is a measure of the likelihood that charge carriers will be separated and contribute to the current produced by the solar cell. It can be characterized by photogenerated current density (J ph) vs effective applied voltage (V eff) measurements.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. J sc: Short for "short-circuit current density."
2. FF: Short for "fill factor."
3. Polymer chain packing.
4. Alkyl side chains.
5. π-π stacking interactions.
6. External quantum efficiency (EQE).
7. Charge carrier mobilities.
8. Charge dissociation probability.

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| J sc |
| FF |
| Polymer chain packing |
| Alkyl side chains |
| π-π stacking interactions |
| External quantum efficiency (EQE) |
| Charge carrier mobilities |
| Charge dissociation probability |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Such a superior device performance is the result of the highest J sc and FF achieved ( Table 3 ) when using 80 °C as a spin - coating temperature compared to those fabricated at 60 or 100 ° C. The decrease in both the J sc and FF could be due to inferior polymer chain packing in the active layer leading to a poor charge transporting network. Besides , the device performance generally varied with the length of alkyl side chains attached onto the polymer backbone. The device efficiency initially increases upon the incorporation of longer alkyl side chains from decyl to tetradecyl reaching a maximum at tetradecyl-substituted PffBB-14 and then declines with further alkyl side chain extension. Importantly , such chain Article length - dependent device performance trend is spin - coating temperature independent. The champion PffBB-14 - based device affords the highest PCE of 9.93% with a V oc of 0.92 V , a J sc of 16.77 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 64.36% . The size of the alkyl side chain is known to affect the processability and interchain interactions of a polymer , which would provide a tool to optimize the π-π stacking interactions of a polymer in the solid state. A size - optimized alkyl side chain would provide a good balance between the π-π stacking interactions of the polymer backbone and the alkyl-alkyl side chain interactions resulting in a highly ordered molecular packing for efficient charge transport. Figure 5a shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) spectra of PffBB-n / PC71BM - based PSCs. Strong and broad photo - to - current responses were observed in the range from 330 to 780 nm in all of these PSCs , in which the absorption above 650 nm was attributed to the polymer aggregationinduced absorption broadening. Remarkably , the PffBB-14based device exhibited a much higher photoconversion Article response ranging from 350 to 500 nm than those of other devices , thus affording the highest J sc among all of these devices. As PffBB-n polymers showed similar absorption properties , the high current density of PffBB-14 - based PSC would result from well - ordered polymer : PC71BMnetwork / packing. J sc derived from the EQE spectra were estimated to be 14.12 , 14.92 , 16.29 , and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 - based devices , respectively , which were in good agreement with those obtained from J-V characterization ( Figure 6 ). Charge Transfer and Recombination. The charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n - based devices were estimated on hole - only and electron - only devices using the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) model , and the results are summarized in Table 4. Indeed , the highest and well - balanced charge carrier mobility of the PffBB-14:PC71BM blend affords a higher J sc and FF than those of other devices. Charge dissociation probability was characterized by photogenerated current density ( J ph ) vs effective applied voltage ( V eff ) measurements.

Let's think step by step.

1. Highest Jsc (short circuit current density) of 16.77 mA cm^-2.
2. Voc (open circuit voltage) of 0.92 V for the champion PffBB-14-based device.
3. FF (fill factor) of 64.36% for the champion PffBB-14-based device.
4. Jsc estimated from EQE (external quantum efficiency) spectra are: 14.12 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10, 14.92 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-12, 16.29 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-14, and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-16 based devices.
5. Charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n-based devices: The hole mobility is 5.5 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-10, 8.1 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-12, 1.1 x 10^-3 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-14, and 5.2 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-16. The electron mobility is 1.1 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-10, 1.6 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-12, 2.2 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-14, and 9.1 x 10^-5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-16.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Jsc of 16.77 mA cm^-2.
2. Voc of 0.92 V.
3. FF of 64.36%.
4. Jsc estimated from EQE spectra: 14.12, 14.92, 16.29, and 14.21 mA cm^-2 for PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16 based devices, respectively.
5. Charge carrier mobilities of PffBB-n-based devices: The hole mobility is 5.5 x 10^-4, 8.1 x 10^-4, 1.1 x 10^-3, and 5.2 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16, respectively. The electron mobility is 1.1 x 10^-4, 1.6 x 10^-4, 2.2 x 10^-4, and 9.1 x 10^-5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16, respectively.
